title: A primer on Statistics using R
section: We believe in making science better. This includes teaching students, postgraduates, and researchers, whether as a refresher of their knowledge or as professional development to expand their skill set.
text:
We believe in making science better. This includes teaching students, postgraduates, and researchers, whether as a refresher of their knowledge or as professional development to expand their skill set.
  
This course will cover data manipulation, visualisation and analyses using R.
It will be tailor-made to the needs of the participant. You can learn about t-tests, linear or logistic regression or other methods relevant to your research.
What’s included:

online workshop with multiple attendees (2 hours)
two one-on-one meetings with an experienced statistical consultant

Presented: Dr. Russell Thomson, with 10+ years helping HDR students.
Cost: $500+GST.
Enquiries: please email Russell.

title: Nicholas Tierney
text: Back to top

title: Leslie New
text:
Dr. Leslie New graduated from Cornell University (BS in Natural Resources, 2003) and the University of St Andrews (PhD in Statistics and Biology, 2010). She remained at St Andrews as a postdoctoral fellow, before continuing her research with the US Marine Mammal Commission and the US Geological Survey at Patuxent Wildlife Research Center. She was tenured in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics and Washington State University, Vancouver, before moving to her current post as an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics, Computer Science and Statistics at Ursinus College.
Her research focuses on statistical ecology, including the practical application of hierarchical Bayesian state-space models, understanding and mitigating human-wildlife conflict, and quantitatively assessing the population consequences of disturbance. Dr. New is particularly interested in the quantification, incorporation and propagation of uncertainty in statistical models used for management and conservation decisions and how to incorporate Star Wars into teaching and research.
For more information about Leslie, see her Google scholar profile.


 Back to top

title: Joanne Potts
text:
Joanne, an ecological statistician based in southern Tasmania, is the director of The Analytical Edge Pty Ltd., a statistical consulting firm she has led since 2012. An Accredited Statistician with the Statistical Society of Australia, Joanne brings a wealth of expertise in survey design and data analysis across a broad spectrum of applications. Her extensive project portfolio includes:

conducting impact assessments and estimating abundance and distribution of invasive, rare and commercially harvested species, including fallow deer, Patagonian toothfish and abalone
developing species distribution and population demographic models
creating models of pest and disease spread to assess biosecurity risks in agricultural settings.

Joanne has successfully delivered many nationally and internationally funded projects to state and federal government agencies, NGOs, private industry and academic researchers. She holds a Bachelor of Science from the University of Melbourne (2003) and a PhD in Applied Statistics from the University of St Andrews, Scotland (2011).
Professional background
After completing her undergraduate degree in Applied Statistics and Environmental Science at the University of Melbourne, Joanne worked as a consultant statistician at the Arthur Rylah Institute for Ecological Research within the Government of Victoria, where she conducted ecological research in a areas such as the impact of salinization, and habitat fragmentation.
In 2006, Joanne moved to the Centre for Research into Ecological and Environmental Modelling at University of St Andrews in Scotland, to undertake her PhD studies. She was supervised by Prof. Stephen Buckland, Dr. Len Thomas, and Dr Anne Savage, and developed methods for incorporating animal movement data into capture-recapture analysis for abundance estimation for small mammals and compared abundance estimation techniques.
See Joanne’s Google Scholar Profile for an up-to-date record of her peer-reviewed scientific publications.

title: Four principles for improved statistical ecology
text:
At the International Statistical Ecology Conference in 2020, there was a round table discussion on developing some guiding principals for ecologists to improve experimental design and to ensure their reporting is transparent and repeatable.
This was a large collaborative project led by Dr Gordana Popovic, involving 18 lead authors from five continents. The Abstract was translated in to four languages other than English - testimony to the diversity of the authorship. Twenty-eight other researchers participated in the round table discussions providing valuable insights in to their experience and feedback in to their experience working in the statistical ecology space.
We agreed upon four guiding principles. They were:

define a focused research question, then plan sampling and analysis to answer it;
develop a model that accounts for the distribution and dependence of your data;
emphasise effect sizes to replace statistical significance with ecological relevance; and
report your methods and findings in sufficient detail so that your research is valid and reproducible.

The article is open access and available here.

title: Evaluation of Models for the AirRater App
text:
AirRater gathers symptoms users have entered into the app and matches these with the environmental conditions at the time. The AirRater App incorporates statistical modelling to predict future symptoms for an individual user. In this statistical consultancy, various statistical modelling techniques were compared using cross validation, to improve the performance of the AirRater App. Models compared included weighted linear discrimination, random forests and generalised linear mixed effects models. Automated PDF Reports were generated for 100 users, using R Markdown.



 Back to top

title: About Us
text:
We specialise in designing high-quality surveys and analysing data to help any industry make evidence-based decisions and develop effective policy.


 



 



About Us



We are a network of statisticians and ecologists. Our work supports diverse stakeholders such as academia, government and the private sector, to achieve their goals.
Our services include:

using risk-based investigative tools to assess the consequences of management actions
designing and analysing clinical trials and observational studies for epidemiological and medical research
designing surveillance protocols to eradicate diseases within agricultural settings
designing surveys to estimate animal and plant abundance
analysing data collected via active underwater acoustics to study migration patterns
designing surveys and analysing data for population modelling, including species spread and population growth in landscapes
applying sophisticated data analysis techniques to publish research in high impact, peer-reviewed journals
delivering technical workshops on statistical topics.

For some examples of our work, see our case studies




 



 

We Work With
 



















Academia






Private industry






Government agencies





  



 



Core Values




Sound methodology that is meaningful for your decision-making
Quality research
Client-focused communication
Working across multi-disciplinary fields
Protecting sensitive information





 



 

Our Clients

Australian Wildlife Conservancy // Baker Institute // Biota // DBCA // DCCEW // Difficult Bird Group // DNRE // Menzies // Speciality Feeds // TLC // UTAS // UWS


 



 

Fields of investigation

Ecology // Epidemiology // Fisheries // Acoustics // Engineering // Medical Research


 



 

Statistical Expertise


Power analyses


Laboratory and field experimental design


Analysing longitudinal data


Establishing long-term monitoring programs to estimate species abundance


Occupancy modelling


Generalised linear modelling


Generalised linear mixed modelling


Generalised additive modelling


Capture-recapture statistics


Spatially explicit capture-recapture modelling


Distance sampling


Survival analysis


Heavily censored data



 



 

Teaching


Upcoming: Understanding and implementing spatially explicit capture-recapture analyses in R. When: Nov 25-29th 2024. Where: in Perth, Western Australia.
On demand: A primer on statistics using R
On demand: Analysis of survey data using SPSS
On demand: Using RMarkdown (and now Quarto) for report writing
On demand: Introduction to estimation and modelling of ecological populations



 



 

Software

R // SPSS // Vortex // MARK // Distance // RAMAS Metapop // Echoview

title: Russell Thomson
text:
Russell is an Accredited Statistician with the Statistical Society of Australia. He completed a PhD at Monash University in mathematical statistics in 1998 at the age of 25. He completed postdoctoral positions at the University of California - Berkeley and Stanford University.
Russell has experience in applying statistics to a very wide range of fields, including epidemiology, bioinformatics and environmental sciences. He garnered this experience in universities and institutes such as the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute for Medical Science, the Menzies Institute for Medical Research, Tasmania and the Institute for Marine and Antarctic Science. At Western Sydney University, he has helped higher degree research students across every discipline and school at the university. Russell’s wide range of expertise is evidenced by his list of more than 100 peer reviewed publications (Google Scholar Profile).
Russell has conducted numerous statistical consultancies while at Western Sydney University and Analytical Edge Pty Ltd, for entities such as Birdlife Australia, the Northern Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils, the Department of Land, Water and Planning and Forest Practices Authority. He led a team to generate a report for the Higher Education Participation and Partnerships Program, within the Department of Education. For further information, you can reach him on russell@theanalyticaledge.com.
Testimonials:
What has been particularly impressive is the approach he takes to the consultation process. As someone who primarily uses mixed methods in my research I come to supervision with some statistical expertise. That said, Russell is able to add value to the ways in which the candidates undertake the statistical analysis of their data ensuring that those analyses are nuanced and tailored both to the nature of the data and, most importantly, the research questions being explored. His relaxed and open manner also means that he is able to work with them without further mystifying statistics since many come to this part of the thesis journey with some trepidation and even fear. They become confident of their ability and are readily able to explain their reasons for undertaking the analyses chosen.
Associate Professor Christine Johnston Associate Dean, International School of Education, Western Sydney University
My students have greatly benefited from the support offered by Dr. Russell Thomson.  He has offered invaluable help with knowledge, resources and advice. These have been of the highest quality and he has been very committed to finding a solution to the problems they have experienced in a timely way.
Yolima Carrillo Senior Lecturer Hawkesbury Institute for the Environment, WSU


 Back to top

title: Roland Proud
text:
Roland Proud is the Managing Director of Cupar Analytics (Scotland, UK), which was founded with the primary objective of promoting sustainable development using state-of-the-art data analytics. The company sits between industry leaders in data collection, management, and reporting, providing insight and analysis. Cupar Analytics Ltd thrives on working with complex, large volume datasets, that are often disorganised and repleat with human-error, providing context, order and new meaning. This is achieved through data cleaning, statistical analysis, modelling, machine learning and AI.
Roland is also an Honorary Research Fellow at the University of St. Andrews and a member of the Pelagic Ecology Research Group. He holds a PhD in Bioacoustics and Marine Ecology (University of St Andrews and University of Tasmania, 2016), an MPhys in Physics and Astrophysics (University of Sheffield, 2008) and a MRes in Ecosystem-based Management of Marine Systems (University of St Andrews, 2012). He has recently worked on EU Horizon 2020 projects “SUMMER” and “Mission Atlantic” to investigate the environmental repercussions of exploitation of mesopelagic resources. In his academic role, he specialises in the development of novel acoustic-based methods of fish biomass estimation, which combine echosounder observations, catch data, eDNA samples and optics.
Please see Roland’s Google Scholar Profile for an update record or his peer reviewed, scientific publications.


 Back to top

title: Hugh McGregor
text:
Dr Hugh McGregor is a wildlife researcher, specialising in the ecology and impacts of feral cats.
He has designed and implemented numerous applied field experiments, including radio-collaring over 100 cats all over Australia.
Hugh did his PhD on how feral cats interact with fire in the Kimberley region of Western Australia, with the University of Tasmania and Australian Wildlife Conservancy. He is currently working in remote South Australia as a post-doctoral researcher under the National Environmental Science Program, Threatened Species Hub, along with collaborating and consulting with numerous conservation organisations.
Joanne Potts and Hugh have been working together for over eight years.

title: Evaluating the impact of the SHINE for KIDS program
text:
SHINE for KIDS supports children and young people affected by the criminal justice system. To evaluate the program, we analysed likert scale style data collected before and after the program using a mixed effects regression model.
Please see here for the program website.



 Back to top

title: Citrus Canker
text:
The main aim of biosecurity response to an incursion is to achieve pest- or disease-free status as quickly as possible. One of the critical initial response activities involves tracing known movements (trace events) to and from an infected or infested property that could spread the pest or pathogen. During an incursion response, managers prioritize individual trace events, allocating surveillance resources to follow-up trace events in order of priority. Prioritizing trace events is difficult and typically subjective.
Joanne developed a simulation model where several dispersal mechanisms spread a pest between areas. The simulation model was developing for citrus canker (caused by Xanthomonas citri), using scenarios from an outbreak of citrus canker that occured in Queensland in 2004. Please read here for more information.



 Back to top

title: Apps And Peer Support For A Healthy Future And Living Well With Diabetes (APHLID)
text:
We will be analysing clinical trial data for the APHLID project, to evaluate a technology-enabled model of care for the support young people with diabetes. Intention-to-treat analyses will be conducted using multiple imputation, to account for missing data.
More information can be found [here](https://westernsydney.edu.au/domtru/projects/trials/aphlid).
